metadata.title: US Federal Government Revenue and Spending Flows, FY2023
sources: US Treasury - Joint Statement on Budget Results for FY2023 (jy1829): Total receipts $4,439.3B, total outlays $6,134.4B
Congressional Budget Office (CBO) - Monthly Budget Review: Summary for FY2023 (pub 59640)
CBO - The Federal Budget in Fiscal Year 2023: An Infographic (pub 59727)
CBO - Mandatory Spending in Fiscal Year 2023: An Infographic (pub 59728)
CBO - Discretionary Spending in Fiscal Year 2023: An Infographic (pub 59729)
Congressional Research Service (CRS) - Federal Grants to State and Local Governments (R40638): $1,083B total grants FY2023
Congressional Research Service (CRS) - Overview of the Federal Tax System in 2024 (R48313)
metadata.notes: Revenue figures are exact from the Treasury Joint Statement (jy1829). Spending figures are from CBO Monthly Budget Reviews and cross-referenced with Treasury data. Budget function totals are rounded to nearest billion. The deficit ($1,695B) represents federal borrowing needed to cover the gap between revenue and outlays. State and local data is approximate, based on Census Bureau and Urban Institute estimates for the most recent available year.

links.description: Individual income tax receipts (49% of federal revenue)
Social insurance and retirement receipts including Social Security and Medicare payroll taxes (36% of revenue)
Corporation income tax receipts (9% of revenue)
Excise taxes on fuel, tobacco, alcohol, etc.
Customs duties on imported goods
Estate and gift tax receipts
Miscellaneous receipts including Federal Reserve deposits and fees
Federal borrowing to cover the FY2023 deficit ($6,134.4B outlays minus $4,439.3B revenue)
Social Security benefit payments (OASI and DI) - 22% of outlays
Medicare spending (Parts A, B, D) - 14% of outlays
Federal share of Medicaid and CHIP ($615.8B in grants to states) - 10% of outlays
Department of Defense and other national defense spending - 13% of outlays
Net interest on the public debt (increased 33% from FY2022)
Veterans benefits, healthcare, disability compensation, and services
SNAP, SSI, EITC/child tax credits, housing assistance, unemployment compensation, and other income security
Other mandatory programs: agriculture subsidies, federal employee retirement, other health programs, etc.
Nondefense discretionary: education, transportation, science, diplomacy, environment, housing, courts, agencies
Medicaid grants to states (56.8% of all federal grants to state/local)
Federal grants for highways ($47.7B), education, housing, community development, and other programs ($1,083B total grants minus $616B Medicaid)
State and local own-source revenue: property taxes, sales taxes, income taxes, fees, charges (approx. based on Census data)
Elementary/secondary education and higher education (largest state/local expenditure)
Public welfare (including state Medicaid match), hospitals, and health programs
Highways, roads, public transit, and transportation infrastructure
Police protection, fire protection, corrections, and judicial/legal services
Parks, utilities, housing, administration, environment, interest on debt, and other services
